Sure, for an old-school hip-hop intro song for "Grandma-ma", we could have a sample-based beat that has a nostalgic and classic feel to it. The chord progression would likely be simple and repetitive, often relying on a single chord or a simple chord progression that sets the foundation for the beat.

Here's a simple chord progression for an old-school hip-hop style intro:

C - G - F - C

This progression has a classic, laid-back feel and could work well as the foundation for the beat.

As for the rap, it could have a playful and light-hearted tone that reflects the comedic elements of the story, while also highlighting her role as a protector of her community. Here's an example of a rap verse:

Verse:
Listen up, 'cause here comes the grandma
She's got a stick and she's not afraid to use it
She's taking care of her neighborhood
She's the one that you should all be in the mood
To thank, 'cause she's saving the day
She's the grandma that's here to play
She's got powers, so don't mess with her
She's the hero that'll make you purr

Just like the chord progression, this rap verse is just an example, you can use it as a starting point and develop it further as you wish. Remember that the rhythm, rhyme and flow are also important elements to take in consideration when writing a rap verse.

Keep in mind that this is just an idea, you can always experiment with different chord progressions and beats, and different raps that align with your artistic vision and the tone of the story.
